title: Weed-Control Machines - Harvest Farm Whately MA

tasks.task: Tending Brassica Crops and Weed Control
subtasks: Discussing farming background and crops grown
Describing weed control methods (cultivation, herbicides, hand hoeing)
Rotating crops to manage diseases and weeds
Using pre-emergent herbicides for seed crops
Implementing three-year crop rotation program

tasks.task: Cultivating Brassica Crops with Tractors and Implements
subtasks: Adjusting equipment for early season weed control (budding cultivators)
Driving a tractor with cub attachments for row cleaning
Breaking up clods with old tools for smooth hilling
Creating even, straight pathways for cultivation
Using adjustable shanks to hill plants and top-dress with fertilizer
Assessing ongoing weed management challenges
Transitioning towards reduced herbicide use and increased cultivation
Monitoring plant growth stages for optimal cultivation timing

tasks.task: Managing Weed Control in Brassica Crops
subtasks: Applying pre-emergent herbicides to new seedings
Using cultivation techniques (hand hoeing, tractor cultivation) to control weeds
Monitoring and adjusting weed control methods over time
Adjusting and operating a cub tractor with budding cages for early season weed control
Using a tractor with sweeps to hill plants and top-dress with fertilizer
Breaking up clods with old tools before hilling
Adhering to a three-year crop rotation program
Rotating crops to different fields each year based on disease and weed pressure
Creating smooth pathways in the field using tractors
Maintaining straight, even rows for optimal machine use
Setting up a cub tractor with budding spurs for early season weed control
Using a cub-themed cultivator (budding cages) in rows to manage early weeds during plant establishment
Breaking up hard clods in the soil with old tools before hilling to prevent plant damage
Adjusting cultivator shanks on another tractor (the “hunter” style) to hill up soil around plants and cover weeds
Driving the hunter-style tractor through fields to complete hilling and apply fertilizer
Adapting equipment setups based on soil conditions (e.g., using road gear when the ground is firm enough)
Applying pre-emergent herbicide to directly-seeded crops to suppress emerging weeds
Utilizing cultivation techniques to manage weeds in the field (both between rows and within rows as the plants grow)
Transitioning towards minimal hand hoeing by optimizing cultivation techniques and equipment use
Planning a three-year crop rotation to mitigate disease and weed issues
Allocating specific crops to fields based on rotation phases and season assignments
Adjusting crop rotation plans in response to persistent weed and disease pressures
Creating smooth, even planting beds using tractors to ensure efficient machinery operation
Ensuring proper bed alignment and surface flatness for accurate implement operation
Monitoring machinery pass efficiency and troubleshooting issues (e.g., the tractor completing a row without the operator)
